The CEFR has been translated into at least?

Can understand with ease virtually everything heard or read. Can summarize information from different spoken and written sources, reconstructing arguments and accounts in a coherent presentation. Can express him/herself spontaneously, very fluently and precisely, differentiating finer shades of meaning even in more complex situations.

Can understand a wide range of demanding, longer texts, and recognize implicit meaning. Can express him/her fluently and spontaneously without much obvious searching for expressions. Can use language flexibly and effectively for social, academic and professional purposes. Can produce clear, well-structured, detailed text on complex subjects, showing controlled use of organizational patterns, connectors and cohesive devices.

Can understand the main ideas of complex texts on both concrete and abstract topics, including technical discussions in his/her field of specialization. Can interact with a degree of fluency and spontaneity that makes regular interaction with native speakers quite possible without strain for either party. Can produce clear, detailed text on a wide range of subjects and explain a viewpoint on a topical issue giving the advantages and disadvantages of various options.

Can understand the main points of clear standard input on familiar matters regularly encountered in work, school, leisure, etc. Can deal with most situations likely to arise whilst travelling in an area where the language is spoken. Can produce simple connected texts on topics which are familiar or of personal interest. Can describe experiences and events, dreams, hopes & ambitions and briefly give reasons and explanations for opinions and plans.

Can understand sentences and frequently used expressions related to areas of most immediate relevance (e.g. very basic personal and family information, shopping, local geography, employment). Can communicate in simple and routine tasks requiring a simple and direct exchange of information on familiar and routine matters. Can describe in simple terms aspects of his/her background, immediate environment and matters in areas of immediate need.

Can understand and use familiar everyday expressions and very basic phrases aimed at the satisfaction of needs of a concrete type. Can introduce him/herself and others and can ask and answer questions about personal details such as where he/she lives, people he/she knows and things he/she has. Can interact in a simple way provided the other person talks slowly and clearly and is prepared to help.
The CEFR describes language learners’ ability in terms of?

In Uzbekistan …….. is seen as a career in a field of educational specialization: it requires a specialized knowledge base obtained through both academic study and practical experience. Nowadays the demonstration of a certain level of proficiency in English as component of certification is required.
the primary education is?

The ability to produce and interpret meaningful utterances which are formed in accordance with the rules of the language concerned and bear their conventional meaning (that meaning which native speakers would normally attach to an utterance when used in isolation). This competence includes vocabulary, grammar, phonetic and phonological, stylistic knowledge.

The awareness of ways in which the choice of language forms is determined by such conditions as setting, relationship between communication partners, communicative intentions, etc. This competence covers the relation between linguistic signals and their contextual/situational meaning.

The ability to use appropriate strategies in the construction and interpretation of texts. It refers to selection, sequencing, and arrangement of words, structures, and utterances to achieve a unified spoken message. This is where the top-down communicative intent and socio-cultural knowledge intersect with the lexical and grammatical resources to express messages and attitudes and to create coherent texts

What includes dialogical genres: I) how to open and close conversations; 2) how to establish and change topics; 3) how to get, hold and relinquish the floor; 4) how to interrupt; 5) how to collaborate and backchannel

When communication is difficult we have to find ways of getting our meaning across or finding out what somebody means; these are communicative strategies, such as rephrasing, asking for clarification, etc.

Every language is situated in a socio-cultural context and implies the use of a particular reference frame which is partly different from that of the FL leaner; sociocultural competence presupposes a certain degree of familiarity with that context. Socio-cultural competence refers to the speaker’s pragmatic knowledge, i.e. how to express messages appropriately within the overall social and cultural context of communication. This includes knowledge of language variation with reference to socio-cultural norms of the target language
Involves both the will and the skill to interact with others, involving motivation, attitude, self confidence, empathy and the ability to handle social situations.

What includes: \) kinesics (body language), non-verbal turn-taking signals, backchannel behaviors, gestures, affect markers, eye contact; 2) proxemies (use of space interlocutors); 3) haptic behavior (touching); nonlinguistic utterances with interactional import (e.g. Ahhh, uh-oh, i/^w/7?) the role of silence and pauses.
The plod of planned results and consequences of imagination.

option4.content: is a simple theoretical information related to grammar material that was learned in the process of speech acquisition.

What does the opening and the closure of the letter signal?

option1.content: The writer is aware of who she is writing to.

option2.content: The writer has copied too much from the task.

option3.content: The writer relies too much on fixed expressions.

option4.content: The writer does not use an appropriate opening and closure.

question.content: What is the main problem with the first sentence of the second paragraph, which functions as the topic sentence of that paragraph?

option4.content: It does not begin with a linking word.

question.content: How is content developed in the second and third paragraphs?

option1.content: The writer does not offer a description of the issue.

option2.content: The writer describes the problem but does not offer solutions.

option3.content: The writer supports each point with a number of relevant examples.

option4.content: The writer uses examples from her own experience to support her point of view.

question.content: Which of the following signals a good range of grammar and vocabulary?

option1.content: The use of the adjectives bad and different in the second paragraph.

option2.content: The use of the structure it is… accurately in three different paragraphs.

option3.content: The use of conjoined sentences and words such as obsession and captain.

option4.content: The repetition of the words violence, fan, and team in different sentences.

question.content: What is the main problem with the organization of this text?

option1.content: The writer does not use connectors.

option3.content: The writer’s opinion is at the end of the letter, not the beginning.

option4.content: The idea that fans are obsessed is interrupted by the second paragraph.

question.content: What does the organization of ideas demonstrate?

option1.content: The writer does not offer a conclusion.

option2.content: The writer’s ideas are not well-connected.

option3.content: The writer shows appropriate, clear organization.

option4.content: The writer shows very basic organization of ideas.

question.content: What does the use of ’cause, Yours, and command-like forms, e.g., you will stop, signal?

option2.content: the writer’s ability to personalize language

option3.content: the writer’s choice of inappropriate register

option4.content: the writer’s attempt to connect with the target reader

question.content: What does the use of hooligans, drunk, innocent, connection, and peaceful signal?

option2.content: the writer’s use of frequent collocations

option3.content: the writer’s choice of inappropriate vocabulary

option4.content: the writer’s confusion between the use of adjectives and nouns

question.content: What is the main strength of this piece of writing?

option1.content: generally appropriate use of verb tenses

option2.content: opens and closes the letter appropriately

option3.content: responds adequately to the three parts of the task

option4.content: maintains theme of drunk fans throughout the text

question.content: Overall, what is the main problem with this piece of writing?

option4.content: lack of ideas regarding the problem and the solution

question.content: Which of the following is an example of an information gap activity?

option1.content: students working alone to complete a cloze passage in a test preparation course

option2.content: students doing a mingling activity to find out who has visited the most countries

option3.content: pairs using a shared table of population figures to rank countries from least to most populated

question.content: What is the recommended course of action to take if a teenager has refused to work in a group?

option1.content: insist in front of the other students that the student should participate

option2.content: call the student’s parents after class to complain about their child’s behavior

option3.content: take the student aside after class and attempt to find a reason for the behavior

question.content: Young learners have come across the word uncle in a text. Which of the following courses of action is most likely to help them remember the new word?

option1.content: Say the word, write the word, have the students say the word and write it three times.

option2.content: Write the word, say the word, have the students say the word and write it three times.

option3.content: Say the word, have the students say the word, write the word, have students write the word three times.

option4.content: have students write the word three times.

question.content: Which of the following would most help an intermediate-level student who has written as essay that is largely irrelevant to the topic?

option1.content: Have the student rewrite the essay.

option2.content: Ask the student to create an outline for the next essay.

option3.content: Get the student to underline key words in the task before writing the next essay.

question.content: Which of the following error correction techniques is most likely to encourage fluency during a speaking activity?

option1.content: Correct errors as they are made.

option2.content: Ask students to correct each other’s mistakes as they hear them.

option3.content: Note down frequent errors and present them at the end of the activity.

question.content: Which of the following criteria is most important when selecting a book for a communicative language course?
Which of the following illustrates students experiencing inductive learning?

option1.content: They follow a model essay in writing one of their own.

option2.content: They underline all examples of simple past tense in a text.

option3.content: They work out the meaning of new vocabulary words from context.

option4.content: They underline all examples of Present perfect tense in a text.

question.content: Which of the following best promotes learner autonomy in writing?

option1.content: Have students provide feedback on each other’s work.

option2.content: Give students a list of things to check for before handing in their work.

option3.content: Encourage students to use as many vocabulary words as they can in their writing.

question.content: Which of the following illustrates an effective use of L1 translation in the classroom?

option1.content: explaining all new vocabulary in a text using the L1

option2.content: clarifying instructions for a complicated task using the L1

option3.content: giving students the option of providing each other with feedback on writing tasks using the L1

question.content: Which of the following statements about listening comprehension is true?

option1.content: It involves both top-down and bottom-up processing.

option2.content: It is rarely improved by a second listening of the same material.

option3.content: It relies on the same sub skills of skimming and scanning as reading.

question.content: Which of the following best illustrates scanning a text?

option1.content: reading fast to get the gist

option2.content: reading fast to find specific information

option3.content: reading carefully to take detailed notes

question.content: Which course of action is likely to be most effective in helping very young learners formulate questions correctly?

option2.content: more natural opportunities to ask questions

option3.content: more study of the rules for forming questions
